author: VICTORIA CRAW
title: ISIS recruit prevention: Active Change Foundation using Facebook, Twitter | Technology | Tech Latest New Technology
text:
IT’S a deceptively low-tech solution. Inside a run-down warehouse in the London borough of Walthamstow is an idea that could be the undoing of the Islamic State.
The graffiti-covered space is filled with couches that have seen better days and copies of the Koran mixed with PCs for dummies. But it’s also home to the Active Change Foundation , an organisation that has managed to achieve things politicians with billion-dollar budgets cannot, stopping the flow of teenagers to Syria one person at a time.
“It’s about doing exactly as the extremists are doing online and offline, mirroring their tactics because it’s a successful approach,” said CEO and founder Hanif Qadir.
“It’s not just a centre that you come in and you can go and play pool, these are all tools of engagement and you do that in the most gentle and least intrusive way.”
The centre is the front line in a huge and growing threat that is indiscriminately targeting teenagers and “stealing” them out of their bedrooms. Mr Qadir said since he first saw the black banners rising in the Middle East three years ago it has become the major threat to young people in his North London borough, not to mention international security.
In the last six months the foundation has stopped seven teens with bags packed ready to fly to Syria — a mixture of young men and women from Muslim and non-Muslim backgrounds. That’s on top of 120 people they prevented joining terrorist networks in the last five years and just a handful of the thousands they come into contact with each year in a bid to counter extremism in all forms.
“In the last two years it’s increased steadily but in the last six months it’s increased rapidly,” Mr Qadir said about the number of people leaving for IS.
“That’s because the IS narrative is a very potent, very strong brand and it works in community dynamics. It works not just in your street environment but in the bedroom in the house itself because of the access to social media.”

‘I’M LUCKY TO BE ALIVE’
It’s a rare case of leading by example for Mr Qadir, who founded the organisation in 2003 after coming back from Afghanistan where he joined al-Qaeda as a foreign fighter in the wake of 9/11.
He left to join the mujahedeen after being outraged at the way the war on terror had led to civilian deaths but quickly became disillusioned with the brutality he witnessed first hand.
“To see the inequality and the hypocrisy for me was unacceptable. I even got more angered against them than I did against the Americans to tell the truth. It was a very hostile situation. I’m very lucky to be alive.”
He sold his business to start the centre but struggled to get recognition for his work. On the verge of bankruptcy, a 2006 plot to blow up an airline hatched by 14 people in the borough led others to sit up and listen.
The organisation now has government funding and is responsible for the #NotinMyName campaign which reached 300 million people around the world and was raised by President Obama at the UN. Their latest campaign #MessagetoISIS is fronted by Mr Qadir’s daughter and designed to beat the terrorist group at their own game.
“It allows young people to see the truth from an individual who is not locked up, who doesn’t feel he is being spied upon,” Mr Qadir said about the centre’s non-judgemental approach.
“We bring truth and reality to the ground to the people who ordinarily wouldn’t accept that.”
Message to ISIS
Glasgow schoolgirl Asqa Mahmood is believed to have fled to Syria. Source: Supplied
The father of Melbourne teen Jake Bilardi blamed himself for son’s death. Source: No Source
The insights have proven critical in the ongoing debate about how to prevent the spread of radicalisation that transcends national borders.
Just last week a 15-year-old UK teen pleaded guilty to inciting terrorism after the court heard he sent thousands of messages to an Australian teen encouraging him to break into a house and behead someone. Other families like that of Melbourne teen Jake Bilardi struggle to realise what is happening before it’s too late and blame themselves for missing the warning signs.
Mr Qadir said it’s easy to see why young people are drawn towards the terrifying brand when simplified information is dumped online and they are shut down by parents, teachers and leaders.
“Our job is to raise that curiosity — to throw a spanner in the works — if they’re on a trajectory towards violent extremism then our job is to raise their curiosity about the extremists they’re gravitating towards.”
